Probability

1. Probability basics

Probabilities with more complex outcomes

What is the probability of rolling a square number when you roll a standard six-sided die?

NOTE: A square number, also called a perfect square, can be written as a product of a number multiplied by itself. For example, 44 is a square number since 4=2×24=2×2.
INSTRUCTIONS: Write your answer as a simplified fraction. Decimal answers will not be accepted.
Answer:

Probability of rolling a square number ==

fraction
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

How many ways can you get this favourable outcome? Which numbers on the die are square? So, how many ways are there of rolling a square number?

STEP: Use the probability formula
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

When you roll a standard die, there are 66 equally likely outcomes: one, two, three, four, five, and six. The favourable outcomes for rolling a square number are shaded below.

P(square number)=Number offavourable outcomesTotal number ofpossible outcomes=26=13P(square number)=favourable outcomesNumber ofpossible outcomesTotal number of=26=13

Therefore, the probability of rolling a square number is 1313.

The probability scale

The diagram below shows the probability scale with an event, named AA, positioned on the scale.

Which of the following is a correct statement about Event AA?

Answer:
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

The probability scale runs from 00 to 11 and it is a measure of how likely an event is. Read the position of AA off the scale to get a measure of its probability. What do you think it means to have a probability of zero? What do you think it means to have a probability of 11?

STEP: Revise the probability scale
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

The probability scale is a way of measuring how likely an event is.

  • Impossible events have a probability of 00. These are events that cannot happen.
  • Certain events have a probability of 11. These are events that will definitely happen.
  • All other events have a probability somewhere between 00 and 11, depending on how likely they are.

In this question, Event AA is placed near zero. This means the event is not impossible, but there is only a small chance that it can happen. We say that Event AA is unlikely.

An example: if there are ten marbles in a bag and only one of them is blue, then the chance of "picking a blue" is unlikely. There is only a small chance this could happen.

STEP: Interpret the position of AA on the scale
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

Therefore P(A)≈10%P(A)≈10%.

Calculating probability as a percentage

  1. Mandilakhe has a bag of 1010 coins. There are three R1R1 coins, two R2R2 coins, and five R5R5 coins. He picks one coin from the bag (without looking inside the bag). What is the probability of not getting a R1R1 coin?

    INSTRUCTIONS:
    • Write your answer as a percentage. Remember that percent means per hundred. For example, 210=20100210=20100 which is 2020 per hundred =20%=20%.
    • The percentage symbol has already been given to you. You only need to type in the number.
    Answer:

    Probability of not getting a R1R1 coin is %%.

    numeric
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    How many ways can you get this favourable outcome? Which coins will correctly give you "not getting a R1R1 coin"?

    STEP: Use the probability formula
    [−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]
    • There are 1010 coins inside the bag.
    • There are 77 favourable outcomes for not getting a R1R1 coin.
    P(not R1 coin)=Number offavourable outcomesTotal number ofpossible outcomes=710P(not R1 coin)=favourable outcomesNumber ofpossible outcomesTotal number of=710
    STEP: Write the probability as a percentage
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    The probability of not getting R1R1 coin is:

    P(not R1)=710=710∖×100∖1%=70%P(not R1)=710=710∖×100∖1%=70%

    This means 7070 per hundred. Therefore the probability of not getting R1R1 coin is 70%70%.

  2. Mandilakhe puts the coin back into the bag. He then goes to a street market and wants to buy a lime which costs R4,00R4,00.

    If he randomly draws one coin from the bag, what is the probability that he will have enough to buy the lime?

    INSTRUCTIONS:
    • Write your answer as a percentage. Remember that percent means per hundred. For example, 210=20100210=20100 which is 2020 per hundred =20%=20%.
    • The percentage symbol has already been given to you. You only need to type in the number.
    Answer:

    Probability of having enough to buy a lime is %%

    numeric
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    How many ways can you get this favourable outcome? Which coins will be enough to buy a lime?

    STEP: Use the probability formula
    [−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]
    • There are 1010 coins inside the bag.
    • There are 55 favourable outcomes that are enough to buy a lime.
    ==P(enough to buy a lime)Number offavourable outcomesTotal number ofpossible outcomes510P(enough to buy a lime)=favourable outcomesNumber ofpossible outcomesTotal number of=510
    STEP: Write the probability as a percentage
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    The probability of having enough to buy a lime is:

    ===P(enough to buy a lime)510510∖×100∖1%50%P(enough to buy a lime)=510=510∖×100∖1%=50%

    This means 5050 per hundred. Therefore the probability of having enough to buy a lime is 50%50%.

Relative frequency and predictions

The image below shows a digital thermometer which measures body temperature in degrees Celcius (°C)(°C).

  1. The nurse at a medical clinic measures the body temperature of each child that visits the clinic. Here are the data recorded from the first 1010 children who visited the clinic yesterday:

    Body temperatures (°C°C)
    11 37,837,8 66 36,236,2
    22 34,834,8 77 38,938,9
    33 38,938,9 88 36,336,3
    44 36,536,5 99 38,638,6
    55 36,736,7 1010 38,938,9

    Here is a table used at the clinic for identifying health problems, such as hypothermia (too cold) or a fever (too hot).

    Diagnosis Body temperature
    Hypothermia Below 35°C35°C
    Normal 36°C−37°C36°C−37°C
    Fever Over 37,5°C37,5°C

    Calculate the relative frequency of children with normal body temperature.

    Answer:

    The relative frequency of children with normal body temperature is .

    numeric
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    How many outcomes have temperatures recorded as normal body temperature? How many trials were recorded in total?

    STEP: Use the formula for relative frequency
    [−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    The relative frequency of normal body temperature is:

    RF(normal)=frequencytotal numberof trialsRF(normal)=frequencyof trialstotal number
    NOTE: We will use the abbreviation RFRF for relative frequency, just as we use PP for probability.
    RF(normal)=410=0,4RF(normal)=410=0,4
    Submit your answer as:

  2. It is helpful to use past information to make predictions. If the nurse can predict roughly how many children come in to the clinic with a fever, this can help to plan how much medication the clinic needs.

    Over the month of March, the clinic saw 1 7851 785 children. The relative frequency of temperatures amongst children in March is below.

    Category of temperature Relative frequency
    Hypothermia 0,180,18
    Normal 0,530,53
    Fever 0,290,29

    In April, the clinic expects to see 2 0002 000 children. How many children can the clinic expect to have a normal temperature?

    Answer:

    The clinic can expect that children out of 2 0002 000 will have a normal temperature.

    numeric
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    After 1 7851 785 patients, the relative frequency was 0,530,53. Use this relative frequency to make a prediction for how many children out of 2 0002 000 we expect will have a normal temperature.

    STEP: Make a prediction for 2 0002 000 children
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]
    To make a prediction, we multiply the relative frequency by the number of children.
    NOTE: We often use information from the past to make predictions about the future. But, this does not mean that we know what will happen. It is just the best guess, given the information that we have.
    • The relative frequency of a normal temperature is 0,530,53.
    • The prediction for 2 0002 000 children is 0,53×2000=10600,53×2000=1060.

    Therefore the clinic can expect that 1 0601 060 children out of 2 0002 000 will have a normal temperature.

    NOTE: Did you notice that the temperature categories listed in the table are not continuous? (One category does not start right after another category ends.) A temperature reading of 38,5°C38,5°C is a very clear result - this child has a fever! However, in reality some readings are trickier. A temperature of 37,3°C37,3°C could be normal, but it might also indicate a mild fever, so in that case a nurse would need more information to decide on the child's health.
    Submit your answer as:

Likelihood: exploring concepts

A cement mixer truck and a Lamborghini have a race, ten times around a race track. Use your understanding of probability to best indicate the likelihood of the following events:

NOTE: A Lamborghini is a super-fast Italian sports car.
Answer:
  1. The cement mixer truck will win the race:
  2. A motorbike will win the race:
  3. The Lamborghini will win the race:
  4. The winner will be the first to complete the race:
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 4 / 4 points left]

Think about how a race works, and think about who or what is actually racing.

STEP: What can happen in this race?
[−4 points ⇒ 0 / 4 points left]

It is possible that either the Lamborghini or the cement mixer truck could win, but we know that the Lamborghini is much faster than the cement mixer truck! The motorbike cannot win since the motorbike is not in this race. In a race, the first to finish is always the winner.

  1. Since a cement mixer truck is usually much slower than a Lamborghini, it is unlikely that the cement mixer truck will win the race.
  2. Since a motorbike is not in the race, it is impossible for the motorbike to win the race.
  3. Since a Lamborghini is usually a lot faster than a cement mixer truck, it is likely that the Lamborghini will win the race.
  4. Since we know how races work, it is certain that the winner will be the first to complete the race.
Submit your answer as: andandand

Probability concepts

You roll a die that has one blue side and five red sides.

How likely is it that you will get a red side?

Answer: It is .
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Picture all the sides. Imagine yourself rolling the die. How likely it is that this will happen?

STEP: How likely is this to happen?
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

We can say the following about the likelihood:

  • You will always get a primary coloured side. All of the sides are a primary colour so this is certain (this will definitely happen).
  • There are five red sides and only one blue side. Therefore it is likely that you will get a red side and unlikely that you will get a blue side.
  • There are no pink sides, therefore it is impossible to get a pink side (this cannot happen).

Correct statement: It is likely that you will get a red side.

Submit your answer as:

Calculating simple probabilities

You roll a standard die that has the numbers 11, 22 , 33, 44, 55, and 66 on it.

What is the probability of getting a seven?

INSTRUCTION: Write your answer as a whole number or a fraction.
Answer:

The probability of getting a seven is .

numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

Use the probability formula to calculate the probability of getting a seven.

To determine the probability, you divide the number of sides with a seven by the total number of sides.

STEP: Use the probability formula
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

We need to use the probability formula to calculate the probability of getting a seven.

The probabilityof an event=Number offavourable outcomesTotal number ofpossible outcomesof an eventThe probability=favourable outcomesNumber ofpossible outcomesTotal number of

The die has zero sides with a seven on, and there is a total of 66 sides on a standard die.

Therefore, the probability of getting a seven =06=06.

Every learner in a class has been asked questions about what after-school activity they enjoy most. (Each learner was allowed to fill in only one activity.)

The school has gathered the following information:

  • 2525 learners love cooking
  • 1010 learners love woodwork
  • 1010 learners love sewing
  • 1010 learners love skipping

What is the probability that a randomly chosen learner loves woodwork the most?

Answer:

P(P(learner loves woodwork the most)=)=

fraction
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

Work out the total number of learners and then the probability of the the event.

STEP: Work out the total number of learners
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

For the probability that the learner loves woodwork the most is

P(loves woodworkthe most)=No. of learners who answered"loves woodwork the most"Total learnersP(the mostloves woodwork)="loves woodwork the most"No. of learners who answeredTotal learners

Every learner answered the question, so we know that:

Total learners=25+10+10+10=55Total learners=25+10+10+10=55
STEP: Use the probability formula
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]
P(loves woodworkthe most)=1055=211P(the mostloves woodwork)=1055=211

Everyday likelihood

Consider the event below and decide the likelihood of the event occuring.

The next baby born in South Africa is a girl.
Answer: The event is .
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

You must think about how often this event usually occurs. Remember that:

  • impossible events never happen.
  • unlikely events usually don't happen, except on rare occassions.
  • equally likely events occur as often as not: there is a 50/5050/50 chance.
  • likely events usually happen, although not always.
  • certain events always happen.
STEP: Decide on the likelihood
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

We must think about how often this event usually occurs. Remember that:

  • impossible events never happen.
  • unlikely events usually don't happen, except on rare occassions.
  • equally likely events occur as often as not: there is a 50/5050/50 chance.
  • likely events usually happen, although not always.
  • certain events always happen.

About half of babies born are girls, and half are boys. This is true even though some families have only girls, and some have only boys. So, the next baby born in South Africa is equally likely to be a girl or a boy.

[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

The probability scale is a way of measuring how likely an event is.

  • Impossible events have a probability of 00. These are events that cannot happen.
  • Certain events have a probability of 11. These are events that will definitely happen.
  • All other events have a probability somewhere between 00 and 11, depending on how likely they are.

In this question, Event AA is placed at 11, meaning that the event is definitely going to happen. We say that it is certain.

An example: if today is 77 March, the probability that "yesterday was 66 March" is 100%100%. We say that it is certain.

Relative frequency and predictions

The image below shows a digital thermometer which measures body temperature in degrees Celcius (°C)(°C).

  1. The nurse at a medical clinic measures the body temperature of each child that visits the clinic. Here are the data recorded from the first 1010 children who visited the clinic yesterday:

    Body temperatures (°C°C)
    11 34,234,2 66 39,739,7
    22 36,336,3 77 38,238,2
    33 36,636,6 88 36,536,5
    44 39,739,7 99 39,939,9
    55 36,136,1 1010 39,739,7

    Here is a table used at the clinic for identifying health problems, such as hypothermia (too cold) or a fever (too hot).

    Diagnosis Body temperature
    Hypothermia Below 35°C35°C
    Normal 36°C−37°C36°C−37°C
    Fever Over 37,5°C37,5°C

    Calculate the relative frequency of children with hypothermia.

    Answer:

    The relative frequency of children with hypothermia is .

    numeric
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    How many outcomes have temperatures recorded as hypothermia? How many trials were recorded in total?

    STEP: Use the formula for relative frequency
    [−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    The relative frequency of hypothermia is:

    RF(hypo)=frequencytotal numberof trialsRF(hypo)=frequencyof trialstotal number
    NOTE: We will use the abbreviation RFRF for relative frequency, just as we use PP for probability.
    RF(hypo)=110=0,1RF(hypo)=110=0,1
    Submit your answer as:

  2. It is helpful to use past information to make predictions. If the nurse can predict roughly how many children come in to the clinic with a fever, this can help to plan how much medication the clinic needs.

    Over the month of April, the clinic saw 2 7452 745 children. The relative frequency of temperatures amongst children in April is below.

    Category of temperature Relative frequency
    Hypothermia 0,20,2
    Normal 0,570,57
    Fever 0,230,23

    In May, the clinic expects to see 3 0003 000 children. How many children can the clinic expect to have a temperature that indicates a fever?

    Answer:

    The clinic can expect that children out of 3 0003 000 will have a temperature that indicates a fever.

    numeric
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    After 2 7452 745 patients, the relative frequency was 0,230,23. Use this relative frequency to make a prediction for how many children out of 3 0003 000 we expect will have a temperature that indicates a fever.

    STEP: Make a prediction for 3 0003 000 children
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]
    To make a prediction, we multiply the relative frequency by the number of children.
    NOTE: We often use information from the past to make predictions about the future. But, this does not mean that we know what will happen. It is just the best guess, given the information that we have.
    • The relative frequency of a temperature that indicates a fever is 0,230,23.
    • The prediction for 3 0003 000 children is 0,23×3000=6900,23×3000=690.

    Therefore the clinic can expect that 690690 children out of 3 0003 000 will have a temperature that indicates a fever.

    NOTE: Did you notice that the temperature categories listed in the table are not continuous? (One category does not start right after another category ends.) A temperature reading of 38,5°C38,5°C is a very clear result - this child has a fever! However, in reality some readings are trickier. A temperature of 37,3°C37,3°C could be normal, but it might also indicate a mild fever, so in that case a nurse would need more information to decide on the child's health.
    Submit your answer as:

Likelihood: exploring concepts

A Formula 1 car and a digger have a race, ten times around a race track. Use your understanding of probability to best indicate the likelihood of the following events:

Answer:
  1. The digger will win the race:
  2. A taxi will win the race:
  3. The Formula 1 car will win the race:
  4. The winner will be the first to complete the race:
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 4 / 4 points left]

Think about how a race works, and think about who or what is actually racing.

STEP: What can happen in this race?
[−4 points ⇒ 0 / 4 points left]

It is possible that either the Formula 1 car or the digger could win, but we know that the Formula 1 car is much faster than the digger! The taxi cannot win since the taxi is not in this race. In a race, the first to finish is always the winner.

  1. Since a digger is usually much slower than a Formula 1 car, it is unlikely that the digger will win the race.
  2. Since a taxi is not in the race, it is impossible for the taxi to win the race.
  3. Since a Formula 1 car is usually a lot faster than a digger, it is likely that the Formula 1 car will win the race.
  4. Since we know how races work, it is certain that the winner will be the first to complete the race.

Probability concepts

You roll a die that has one red side and five yellow sides.

How likely is it that you will get a red side?

Answer: It is .
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Picture all the sides. Imagine yourself rolling the die. How likely it is that this will happen?

STEP: How likely is this to happen?
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

We can say the following about the likelihood:

  • You will always get a primary coloured side. All of the sides are a primary colour so this is certain (this will definitely happen).
  • There are five yellow sides and only one red side. Therefore it is likely that you will get a yellow side and unlikely that you will get a red side.
  • There are no pink sides, therefore it is impossible to get a pink side (this cannot happen).

Correct statement: It is unlikely that you will get a red side.

What is the probability of getting a R1R1 coin?

INSTRUCTION: Write your answer as a whole number, a fraction, or a decimal.
Answer:

The probability of getting a R1R1 coin is .

numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

Use the probability formula to calculate the probability of getting a R1R1 coin.

To determine the probability, you divide the number of R1R1 coins by the total number of coins.

STEP: Use the probability formula
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

We need to use the probability formula to calculate the probability of getting a R1R1 coin.

The probabilityof an event=Number offavourable outcomesTotal number ofpossible outcomesof an eventThe probability=favourable outcomesNumber ofpossible outcomesTotal number of

In the pocket, there are two R1R1 coins and there is a total of 1010 coins in the pocket.

Therefore, the probability of getting a R1R1 coin =210=15=210=15.

2. Probability calculations

Working backwards from probability

Riaan has a bag of marbles. There are 88 red marbles in the bag. If Riaan takes one marble out of the bag (without looking), the probability that he gets a red marble is 20%20%.

How many marbles are there in the bag in total?

Answer:

There are marbles in the bag in total.

numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]

Fill the information that you have into the probability formula.

STEP: Write down the probability formula and fill in the given information
[−1 point ⇒ 2 / 3 points left]
P(getting ared marble)=number ofred marblestotal marblesP(red marblegetting a)=red marblesnumber oftotal marbles

Let the total number of marbles in the bag be TT.

20%=8T20%=8T

We will solve this equation by inspection. To do so, we must first write both sides as fractions.

STEP: Write the probability as a simplified fraction
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 3 points left]
NOTE: Remember that %% means percent, in other words, per hundred. So 20%20% means 2020 per hundred, in other words 2010020100.
2010015=8T=8T20100=8T15=8T
STEP: Solve the equation by inspection
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

The fractions are equivalent.

We can see that the 11 has been multiplied by 88 to get 88. So, we must multiply 55 by 88 to get TT.

T=5×8=40T=5×8=40

So, there are 4040 total marbles in the bag.

3. Practical applications

Understanding relative frequency

Limpho tossed a coin 99 times and recorded the outcomes of this experiment in the tally table below.

Side of coin Tally marks
Heads
Tails
Answer:

The of getting tails is 77.

HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]
  • Frequency is the number of times that an outcome occurs in an experiment.
  • The relative frequency of an outcome in an experiment is found by dividing the frequency of that outcome by the total number of times that the experiment was conducted.
  • The probability of an event is found by dividing the number of favourable outcomes by the total possible outcomes. It does not depend on the outcome of a particular experiment.
STEP: Choose the correct description
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

The probability of getting tails when we toss a coin is always 1212.

But, when we toss a coin in an experiment, we will not necessarily get tails half of the time. Events in the real world do not always work out as we might expect.

In this experiment, Limpho got tails 77 times. This is called frequency.

If we take this frequency and divide it by the total number of times the experiment was conducted, we get relative frequency. In this experiment, the relative frequency of getting tails is 7979.

NOTE: Relative frequency does not have to be the same as probability.

77 is the number of times that tails occured in the experiment.

So, the frequency of getting tails is 77.

TIP: Tally marks are a way of keeping track of the number of times that each outcome has occurred. Each time that Limpho gets a tails, she will draw a line (called a tally mark). When she gets the fifth tails, she crosses out the four marks. So four crossed out lines actually means five tails.

You are dealt the following cards:

  • 88 of diamonds ♢♢
  • 55 of clubs ♣♣

  • King of hearts ♡♡

What is the probability that your opponent might get a card from the spades suit from your hand?

INSTRUCTION: Give your answer in its simplest form.
Answer:

The probability that your opponent might get a card from the spades suit from your hand is .

fraction

P=Number of favourable outcomesTotal number of possible outcomesP=favourable outcomesNumber of possible outcomesTotal number of 
STEP: Use the formula for the probability of any event
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

We need to calculate the probability that your opponent might get a card from the spades suit from your hand. We need to use the probability formula to answer this question. The probability, PP, of an event is:

P=Number of favourable outcomesTotal number of possible outcomesP=favourable outcomesNumber of possible outcomesTotal number of 

We need to determine:

  1. the number of favourable outcomes; and
  2. the total number of possible outcomes.

The total number of possible outcomes is the number of cards in your hand. In this case, this is 1111.

The number of ways your opponent might get a card from the spades suit gives us the number of favourable outcomes. In this case, this number is 44.

We can now go back to the probability formula and plug in these values.

P=Number of favourable outcomesTotal number of possible outcomes=411P=favourable outcomesNumber of possible outcomesTotal number of =411

The probability that your opponent might get a card from the spades suit from your hand is 411411.

    B ✘ The relative frequency of an outcome in an experiment is never equal to the probability of that outcome.

    The relative frequency of an outcome can be equal to the probability of that outcome, but it is often different.

    This statement is true.

Theoretical probability

A student finds a deck of 52 cards and then takes one card from the deck. What is the probability that the card's suit is Hearts?

INSTRUCTION: Write your answer as a simplified fraction.
Answer: The probability is .
fraction
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

You must use the formula for probability:

P(E)=n(E)n(S)P(E)=n(E)n(S)
STEP: Use the formula for theoretical probability
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

To calculate probability, we first recall the formula:

P(E)=n(E)n(S)P(E)=n(E)n(S)

Secondly we identify the values for the situation described in the question:

n(E)n(S)=number of outcomes in the event set=13=number of possible outcomes in the sample space=52n(E)=number of outcomes in the event set=13n(S)=number of possible outcomes in the sample space=52

Finally, we substitute into the formula and work out the answer.

P(E)P(E)=n(E)n(S)=1352=14P(E)=n(E)n(S)=1352P(E)=14

Therefore, the probability that the card's suit is Hearts =14=14.

Relative frequency and probability graphed

Akinbode tosses a coin 1010 times. He draws two graphs based on the results of this experiment, shown below:

One graph shows the relative frequency of getting heads after each toss. The other shows the probability of getting heads on a single coin toss.

  1. Select the correct answer to complete the following:

    Answer:

    The graph of represents the probability of getting heads. As we increase the number of we expect the relative frequency to get closer to the probability.

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    One is a line graph and one is a broken-line graph. Why is this?

    What is the difference between relative frequency and probability?

    STEP: Which line on the graph is showing probability and which is showing relative frequency?
    [−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]
    The probability of getting heads on a single toss is always 1212 since one out of the two faces on a coin is heads. The likelihood or probability stays the same - it does not matter how many times you toss the coin.
    The relative frequency of getting heads is calculated as the number of times you got heads, divided by the number of times you tossed the coin. The relative frequency changes depending on what happened and how many times you tossed the coin.

    We can see the output of Graph ff stays the same. Graph ff is a horizontal line graph showing a constant output of 1212 which is shown as the decimal 0,50,5. The output does not change with the number of coin tosses. So, Graph ff shows the probability.

    The graph of ff represents the probability of getting heads.

    STEP: Look at what happens as the coin is tossed more times
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]
    A trend is a general direction in which something is developing or changing.

    Just like pages in a book, we read graphs from left to right. As more coins are tossed (look from zero tosses to ten tosses) we can see a trend. At first we can see the relative frequency can be quite different from the probability. But as we toss more coins, we can expect the relative frequency to get closer to the probability.

    The graphs show that:

    • relative frequency is not always equal to probability.
    • we can expect the relative frequency to get closer to probability as we toss the coin more times.

    As we increase the number of coin tosses we expect the relative frequency to get closer to the probability.

    NOTE: Tally marks are used for counting scores in groups of 55. Each stick, or tally marking, means 11 score, so |=1|=1 and |||=3|||=3. After four tally markings, a diagonal line is drawn to show a group of 55.

    The frequency of Khayalethu winning is 22.

    Khayalethu and Likengkeng played Mancala times yesterday.

    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    • Likengkeng won 66 times.

Coin experiment

Danjuma tosses a fair coin 100100 times.

  1. How many times would Danjuma expect to get heads in this experiment?

    Answer:

    Danjuma would expect to get heads times.

    numeric
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    What is the probability of getting heads on a single coin toss?

    STEP: Use the probability to determinet the expected number of outcomes
    [−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    When you toss a coin, you can either get heads or tails, and both are equally likely. So, the probability of getting heads on a fair coin is 1212.

    If we toss a coin 100100 times, we expect half of those to be heads. So we expect to get

    12×100=50 heads12×100=50 heads
    NOTE: Just because we expect to get 5050 heads does not mean that this will actually happen. This is just our best estimate.
    Submit your answer as:

  2. Danjuma now does the experiment. He does not get heads once.

    How likely is this outcome?

    Answer: This outcome is .
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    How does this outcome compare with what was expected?

    STEP: Evaluate the likelihood
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    Just because we expect 5050 heads, this does not mean that 5050 heads will definitely happen when the coin is tossed 100100 times. Experiments can produce outcomes that we do not expect, like this one did.

    Danjuma did not get heads once, which means that he got 00 heads in 100100 coin tosses. This is very unlikely! But, it is still possible. So, the best choice from the options is unlikely.

Answer: The probability of selecting a circle is .
fraction

P=Number of favourable outcomesTotal number of possible outcomesP=favourable outcomesNumber of possible outcomesTotal number of 
STEP: Use the probability formula to answer the question
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

We need to determine the probability of selecting a circle from a group of 77 shapes. We need to use the probability formula to answer this question. The probability, PP, of an event is:

P=Number of favourable outcomesTotal number of possible outcomesP=favourable outcomesNumber of possible outcomesTotal number of 
  • We are asked the probability of selecting a circle.
  • Favourable outcomes: there are no circles.
  • Possible outcomes: there are 77 shapes shown in total.
P=Number of favourable outcomesTotal number of possible outcomes=07P=favourable outcomesNumber of possible outcomesTotal number of =07

The probability of selecting a circle is 00.

Exercises

Understanding relative frequency

Siyabonga tossed a coin 1111 times and recorded the outcomes of this experiment in the tally table below.

Side of coin Tally marks
Heads
Tails
Answer:

The of getting heads is 44.

HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]
  • Frequency is the number of times that an outcome occurs in an experiment.
  • The relative frequency of an outcome in an experiment is found by dividing the frequency of that outcome by the total number of times that the experiment was conducted.
  • The probability of an event is found by dividing the number of favourable outcomes by the total possible outcomes. It does not depend on the outcome of a particular experiment.
STEP: Choose the correct description
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

The probability of getting heads when we toss a coin is always 1212.

But, when we toss a coin in an experiment, we will not necessarily get heads half of the time. Events in the real world do not always work out as we might expect.

In this experiment, Siyabonga got heads 44 times. This is called frequency.

If we take this frequency and divide it by the total number of times the experiment was conducted, we get relative frequency. In this experiment, the relative frequency of getting heads is 411411.

NOTE: Relative frequency does not have to be the same as probability.

44 is the number of times that heads occured in the experiment.

So, the frequency of getting heads is 44.

TIP: Tally marks are a way of keeping track of the number of times that each outcome has occurred. Each time that Siyabonga gets a heads, he will draw a line (called a tally mark). When he gets the fifth heads, he crosses out the four marks. So four crossed out lines actually means five heads.
Submit your answer as:

Go fish!

You are dealt the following cards:

  • Ace of spades ♠♠
  • 55 of spades ♠♠
  • 77 of hearts ♡♡
  • 1010 of hearts ♡♡
  • 88 of hearts ♡♡
  • 77 of diamonds ♢♢
  • Jack of diamonds ♢♢
  • Ace of diamonds ♢♢
  • 33 of clubs ♣♣
  • 77 of spades ♠♠
  • 88 of clubs ♣♣
  • 99 of hearts ♡♡

What is the probability that your opponent might get a picture card from your hand? (Ace, King, Queen, and Jack).

INSTRUCTION: Give your answer in its simplest form.
Answer:

The probability that your opponent might get a picture card from your hand is .

fraction
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

Use the probability formula to answer this question:

P=Number of favourable outcomesTotal number of possible outcomesP=favourable outcomesNumber of possible outcomesTotal number of 
STEP: Use the formula for the probability of any event
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

We need to calculate the probability that your opponent might get a picture card from your hand. We need to use the probability formula to answer this question. The probability, PP, of an event is:

P=Number of favourable outcomesTotal number of possible outcomesP=favourable outcomesNumber of possible outcomesTotal number of 

We need to determine:

  1. the number of favourable outcomes; and
  2. the total number of possible outcomes.

The total number of possible outcomes is the number of cards in your hand. In this case, this is 1212.

The number of ways your opponent might get a picture card gives us the number of favourable outcomes. In this case, this number is 33.

We can now go back to the probability formula and plug in these values.

P=Number of favourable outcomesTotal number of possible outcomes=312=14P=favourable outcomesNumber of possible outcomesTotal number of =312=14

The probability that your opponent might get a picture card from your hand is 1414.

  3. Compare the relative frequency of rolling a four in this experiment with the probability of rolling a four. Then choose the most correct options below.

    Answer:

    In this experiment, the relative frequency is the probability.

    Which one of the following statements about this comparison is correct?

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]

    Compare the relative frequency and probability. Are they the same or different? Will this always be the case?

    STEP: Compare the relative frequency and probability
    [−2 points ⇒ 1 / 3 points left]

    We have already worked out the following relative frequency and probability of rolling a four:

    • Probability =0,17=0,17
    • Relative frequency =0,13=0,13

    The relative frequency is a measure of what actually happened in an experiment. We expect this to be close to the probability of that outcome, especially when we do many trials. But, this does not always happen. What happens in the real world is not always what we expect to happen.

    The relative frequency of rolling a four in this experiment was 0,130,13. The difference between the probability and the relative frequency is 0,040,04. So the relative frequency is within 0,10,1 of the probability; the values are very close to each other.

    STEP: Choose the correct option about this comparision
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]
    A ✘ The relative frequency of an outcome in an experiment must always be equal to the probability of that outcome.
    The relative frequency of an outcome can be equal to the probability of that outcome, but it is often different.
    B ✘ The relative frequency of an outcome in an experiment is never equal to the probability of that outcome.
    The relative frequency of an outcome is often different to the probability of that outcome, but it can be the same.
    C ✘ In an experiment, the relative frequency of an outcome should be equal to the probability of that outcome.
    As we repeat experiments more times, we expect the relative frequency of an outcome to get closer to the probability of that outcome. But, this does not mean that the two should be equal.
    D ✔ The relative frequency of an outcome in an experiment does not have to be equal to the probability of that outcome.
    This statement is true.

Theoretical probability

A student finds a deck of 52 cards and then takes one card from the deck. What is the probability that the card is a Queen?

INSTRUCTION: Write your answer as a decimal (correct to 2 decimal places).
Answer: The probability is .
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

You must use the formula for probability:

P(E)=n(E)n(S)P(E)=n(E)n(S)
STEP: Use the formula for theoretical probability
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

To calculate probability, we first recall the formula:

P(E)=n(E)n(S)P(E)=n(E)n(S)

Secondly we identify the values for the situation described in the question:

n(E)n(S)=number of outcomes in the event set=4=number of possible outcomes in the sample space=52n(E)=number of outcomes in the event set=4n(S)=number of possible outcomes in the sample space=52

Finally, we substitute into the formula and work out the answer.

P(E)P(E)=n(E)n(S)=452≈0,0769P(E)=n(E)n(S)=452P(E)≈0,0769

Remember that the question says your answer should be "correct to 2 decimal places," which means rounding to two places. Therefore, the probability that the card is a Queen ≈0,08≈0,08.

numeric

P(E)=n(E)n(S)P(E)=n(E)n(S)

n(E)n(S)=number of outcomes in the event set=50=number of possible outcomes in the sample space=100n(E)=number of outcomes in the event set=50n(S)=number of possible outcomes in the sample space=100

Finally, we substitute into the formula and work out the answer.

P(E)P(E)=n(E)n(S)=50100=0,5P(E)=n(E)n(S)=50100P(E)=0,5

Simple calculations with relative frequency

Ekene and Musa love playing Mancala. Mancala is a two-player game using tokens such as stones, marbles, or beans. The tokens are placed in rows of sections carved out of wood or drawn into sand.

The aim of the game is to cleverly move all your tokens to your "Mancala", the big section at the end, before your opponent.

Here are the game scores from yesterday:

Ekene won Musa won

Answer the following questions:

INSTRUCTION: Do not round off decimal answers.
Answer:
  1. The relative frequency of Ekene winning is .
  2. Complete: (relative frequency of Ekene winning) + (relative frequency of Musa winning) is .
  3. The sum of all the relative frequencies equals 11.
numeric
one-of
type(string)

[−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]

STEP: Calculate the relative frequency of the event "Ekene wins"
[−1 point ⇒ 2 / 3 points left]
NOTE: In order to make the solution easier to read, we will use the abbreviation RFRF for Relative Frequency, just as we use PP for Probability.
RF=number of timesthe event occurredtotal number oftrials conductedRF=the event occurrednumber of timestrials conductedtotal number of

From the table, we find:

  • the frequency of Ekene winning is 1515
  • the total number of trials is 15+115+1
RF(Ekene wins)=1516=0,9375RF(Ekene wins)=1516=0,9375

∴RF(Ekene wins)+RF(Musa wins)=0,9375+0,0625=1∴RF(Ekene wins)+RF(Musa wins)=0,9375+0,0625=1

Trick dice: experimental probability vs theoretical probability

This "Magic Trick Dice" is said to help you roll lots of sixes. (This would be a bonus for many games!)

Let us see what actually happened after 4848 rolls. The table below shows the frequencies that were recorded:

  1. Calculate the relative frequency of rolling a six using this "Magic Trick Dice".

    Answer:

    The relative frequency of rolling a six is .

    one-of
    type(numeric.noerror)
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    How many times was a six rolled? How many times was the dice rolled in total?

    STEP: Use the table to determine the frequency of rolling a six and then calculate the relative frequency
    [−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    We can see from the table that six was rolled 2424 times.

    Use the formula:

    RF=number ofsuccessestotal numberof trialsRF=successesnumber ofof trialstotal number
    The relative frequency of an event is the number of times that the event occurs in an experiment, divided by the total number of trials.

    We see from the table:

    • six was rolled 2424 times.
    • the dice was rolled 4848 times in total.
    RF(rolling a six)=2448=12RF(rolling a six)=2448=12
    Submit your answer as:

  2. Based on the outcome relative frequency of this experiment, how many times would you expect to roll a six in 2 1002 100 rolls of this "Magic Trick Dice"?

    Answer:

    You would expect to roll sixes in 2 1002 100 rolls of this "Magic Trick Dice".

    numeric
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Use the relative frequency of rolling a six with a "Magic Trick Dice" to make a prediction.

    STEP: Use the relative frequency of rolling a six with this "Magic Trick Dice"
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]
    To make a prediction we multiply the relative frequency by the number of rolls.
    NOTE: We often use information from the past to make predictions about the future. But, this does not mean that we know what will happen. It is just the best guess, given the information that we have.

    The relative frequency of rolling a six with the "Magic Trick Dice" is 1212.

    The prediction for 2 1002 100 rolls is

    12×2100=105012×2100=1050

    Therefore we can expect to roll 1 0501 050 sixes in 2 1002 100 rolls.

    Submit your answer as:

  3. How many times would you expect to roll a six in 2 1002 100 rolls of a fair dice?

    Answer:

    If we rolled a fair dice 2 1002 100 times we would expect to roll sixes.

    numeric
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    Use the probability of rolling a six with a fair dice to make a prediction.

    STEP: What is the probability of rolling a six on a fair dice?
    [−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

    A fair dice is a dice with 66 equally likely outcomes. You may have seen the phrase "a standard dice" - this also means a dice with equally likely outcomes.

    The probability of an event is the number of favourable outcomes divided by the total number of outcomes.
    P(rolling a six)=number of favourable outcomestotal numberof outcomesP(rolling a six)=favourable outcomesnumber of of outcomestotal number

    The number six is 11 of the 66 equally likely outcomes on a standard dice.

    P(rolling a six)=16P(rolling a six)=16
    STEP: Use the probability of rolling a six on a fair dice to predict how many sixes will be rolled in 2 1002 100 rolls
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]
    To make a prediction we multiply the probability by the number of rolls.
    • The probability of rolling a six with a fair dice is 1616.
    • The prediction for 2 1002 100 rolls is
    16×2100=35016×2100=350

    Therefore we can expect to roll 350350 sixes in 2 1002 100 rolls.

Relative frequency and probability graphed

Kamogelo tosses a coin 1010 times. He draws two graphs based on the results of this experiment, shown below:

One graph shows the relative frequency of getting heads after each toss. The other shows the probability of getting heads on a single coin toss.

  1. Select the correct answer to complete the following:

    Answer:

    The graph of represents the relative frequency of getting heads. When we toss the coin more times, we expect the relative frequency to get the probability.

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    One is a line graph and one is a broken-line graph. Why is this?

    What is the difference between relative frequency and probability?

    STEP: Which line on the graph is showing probability and which is showing relative frequency?
    [−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]
    The probability of getting heads on a single toss is always 1212 since one out of the two faces on a coin is heads. The likelihood or probability stays the same - it does not matter how many times you toss the coin.
    The relative frequency of getting heads is calculated as the number of times you got heads, divided by the number of times you tossed the coin. The relative frequency changes depending on what happened and how many times you tossed the coin.

    We can see the output of Graph gg changes. Graph gg is a broken-line graph showing a decimal output after each coin toss. These points are joined to form the broken-line. The output can change each time you toss the coin - it is not constant. So, Graph gg shows the relative frequency.

    The graph of gg represents the relative frequency of getting heads.

    STEP: Look at what happens as the coin is tossed more times
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]
    A trend is a general direction in which something is developing or changing.

    Just like pages in a book, we read graphs from left to right. As more coins are tossed (look from zero tosses to ten tosses) we can see a trend. At first we can see the relative frequency can be quite different from the probability. But as we toss more coins, we can expect the relative frequency to get closer to the probability.

    The probability does not change but the relative frequency does!

    The graphs show that:

    • relative frequency is not always equal to probability.
    • we can expect the relative frequency to get closer to probability as we toss the coin more times.

    When we toss the coin more times, we expect the relative frequency to get closer to the probability.

    Submit your answer as: and

  2. Use the graph to determine whether the outcome of the first coin toss in the experiment was heads or tails.

    Answer:

    The outcome of the first coin toss was:

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    What does the graph show for the relative frequency after one toss?

    STEP: Look at the relative frequency value on Graph gg after one toss
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    The coordinate (1,1)(1,1) is on Graph gg. This means after one toss, the relative frequency of getting heads was 11.

    RF1∴=numberof headstotal numberof tosses=numberof heads1number of heads=1RF=of headsnumberof tossestotal number1=of headsnumber1∴number of heads=1

    The outcome of the first coin toss was heads.

Relative frequency and tallies

Justine and Gabisile love playing Mancala. Mancala is a two-player game using tokens such as stones, marbles, or beans. The tokens are placed in rows of sections carved out of wood or drawn into sand.

The aim of the game is to cleverly move all your tokens to your "Mancala", the big section at the end, before your opponent.

Here are the game scores from yesterday:

Justine won Gabisile won

  1. How many possible outcomes are there for one game?

    NOTE: In this version of Mancala, there is one winner. The outcome cannot be a draw.
    Answer:

    There are possible outcomes for this game of Mancala.

    numeric
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    How many outcomes can happen when the game is played?

    STEP: Think about the possible outcomes
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    For a single game of Mancala, there are 22 possible outcomes:

    1. Justine will win and Gabisile will lose.
    2. Gabisile will win and Justine will lose.

    There are 22 possible outcomes for this Mancala game.

    Submit your answer as:

  2. What is the frequency of the event "Justine wins"?

    Answer:

    The frequency of Justine winning is .

    numeric
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    The frequency of Justine winning is the number of times that she won.

    STEP: How many times did Justine win?
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    The number of times each outcome happens is called the frequency.

    You can see in the tally table that Justine won 66 times.

    NOTE: Tally marks are used for counting scores in groups of 55. Each stick, or tally marking, means 11 score, so |=1|=1 and |||=3|||=3. After four tally markings, a diagonal line is drawn to show a group of 55.

    The frequency of Justine winning is 66.

    Submit your answer as:

  3. How many times did Justine and Gabisile play Mancala yesterday?

    Answer:

    Justine and Gabisile played Mancala times yesterday.

    numeric
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    The frequency of Justine winning is 66, and the frequency of Gabisile winning is 44. How many games were played in total?

    STEP: How many games were played in total?
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    To calculate the total number of trials conducted in this experiment, we remember:

    • A game of Mancala has only two possible outcomes.
    • Justine won 66 times.
    • Gabisile won 44 times.

    So they must have played 6+4=106+4=10 times in total.

Relative frequency and probability terminology

Select the correct word or statement from the list to complete the sentence below.

Answer:

The term relative frequency is also known as the .

HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

You may find it helpful to revise the terms probability, relative frequency, theoretical probability, experimental probability, outcome, event, likelihood, experiment, and trial.

STEP: Recall the definition of experimental probability
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]
The term relative frequency is also known as the experimental probability. The relative frequency of an event is the number of times that event occurs during experimental trials, divided by the total number of trials conducted.

Therefore the term relative frequency is also known as the experimental probability.

Submit your answer as:

Relative frequency and probability terminology

Select the correct word or statement from the list to complete the sentence below.

Answer:

The result of a trial in an experiment is called the .

HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

You may find it helpful to revise the terms probability, relative frequency, theoretical probability, experimental probability, outcome, event, likelihood, experiment, and trial.

STEP: Recall what you know about probability experiments
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]
In an experiment, a trial is the procedure that takes place to test the experiment. A result of a trial is called an outcome, and the specific outcome (or set of outcomes) is known as an event.

Therefore the result of a trial in an experiment is called the outcome.

Coin experiment

Habubakar tosses a fair coin 160160 times.

  1. How many times would Habubakar expect to get tails in this experiment?

    Answer:

    Habubakar would expect to get tails times.

    numeric
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    What is the probability of getting tails on a single coin toss?

    STEP: Use the probability to determinet the expected number of outcomes
    [−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    When you toss a coin, you can either get heads or tails, and both are equally likely. So, the probability of getting tails on a fair coin is 1212.

    If we toss a coin 160160 times, we expect half of those to be tails. So we expect to get

    12×160=80 tails12×160=80 tails
    NOTE: Just because we expect to get 8080 tails does not mean that this will actually happen. This is just our best estimate.
    Submit your answer as:

  2. Habubakar now does the experiment. He gets tails 159159 times.

    How likely is this outcome?

    Answer: This outcome is .
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    How does this outcome compare with what was expected?

    STEP: Evaluate the likelihood
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    Just because we expect 8080 tails, this does not mean that 8080 tails will definitely happen when the coin is tossed 160160 times. Experiments can produce outcomes that we do not expect, like this one did.

    Habubakar got tails 159159 times, which means that he got 159159 tails in 160160 coin tosses. This is very unlikely! But, it is still possible. So, the best choice from the options is unlikely.

    Submit your answer as:

Probability formula

What is the probability of selecting a triangle from the shapes below?

INSTRUCTION: Write the probability as a simplified fraction. Decimal answers will not be accepted.
Answer: The probability of selecting a triangle is .
fraction
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

Use the probability formula:

P=Number of favourable outcomesTotal number of possible outcomesP=favourable outcomesNumber of possible outcomesTotal number of 
STEP: Use the probability formula to answer the question
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

We need to determine the probability of selecting a triangle from a group of 88 shapes. We need to use the probability formula to answer this question. The probability, PP, of an event is:

P=Number of favourable outcomesTotal number of possible outcomesP=favourable outcomesNumber of possible outcomesTotal number of 
  • We are asked the probability of selecting a triangle.
  • Favourable outcomes: there are 66 triangles.
  • Possible outcomes: there are 88 shapes shown in total.
P=Number of favourable outcomesTotal number of possible outcomes=68P=favourable outcomesNumber of possible outcomesTotal number of =68

We now need to simplify this fraction.

P=68=34P=68=34

The probability of selecting a triangle is 3434.
